metadata.chief_complaint: fever x2 days, new penicillin allergy discovered

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Hi, I'm Dr. Patel. This is Olivia? What's going on today?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Hi. She's had a fever since Wednesday. It's been getting up to 102, sometimes higher.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Okay, so about two days now. Has she been eating and drinking normally?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: She's drinking okay, maybe a little less than usual. But she's been really fussy and not sleeping well.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Any cough, runny nose, pulling at her ears?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Um, a little bit of a runny nose. Clear stuff. I haven't noticed her pulling at her ears.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Any vomiting or diarrhea?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: No, nothing like that.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Good. Any rashes?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Actually, yes. She had a rash last week, but that was from the antibiotic she was on.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Oh, tell me more about that. What antibiotic was she taking?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: She had an ear infection about ten days ago and they gave her amoxicillin. The pink liquid. She took it for maybe four days and then broke out in this red bumpy rash all over her trunk.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Did the rash itch? Any trouble breathing or swelling of her face or lips?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: It seemed itchy, she was kind of squirmy. But no, no swelling or breathing problems. The doctor at urgent care said to stop the amoxicillin and the rash went away in a couple days.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Okay, that's really important information. So she had a reaction to amoxicillin. That's a penicillin-type antibiotic, so we'll want to avoid all penicillins going forward. I'm going to add that as an allergy in her chart right now. Penicillin allergy, reaction was rash.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Oh, I didn't realize it was a whole class of medicines. Is that a big deal?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: It's good to know because there are several antibiotics in that family we'll need to avoid. But there are plenty of alternatives, so it's not a problem, we just need to have it documented.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Okay. Should I tell other doctors about this?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Absolutely. Any time she sees a new provider or goes to a pharmacy, make sure they know about the penicillin allergy. Now, let me take a look at her.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I'm going to listen to her heart and lungs first. Heart sounds good. Lungs are clear, no wheezing or crackles.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Let me check her ears. Left ear looks good. Right ear... there's some redness and fluid behind the eardrum. Looks like another ear infection.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Oh no, another one? But we can't use that antibiotic anymore.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Right, we'll use a different one. I'm going to prescribe Cefdinir, it's an orange-flavored liquid. It's not in the penicillin family so it should be safe for her.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Okay. How long does she take it?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Ten days, once a day. It's nice because it's just once daily dosing. You can give it with food.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: And what about the fever? Should I keep giving Tylenol?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Yes, you can alternate Tylenol and Motrin every three to four hours if needed for comfort. The fever should come down within 48 to 72 hours once the antibiotic kicks in.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: What if it doesn't get better?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: If she's not improving after three days, or if she seems worse, higher fevers, not drinking, more lethargic, call us right away. But I expect she'll turn the corner pretty quickly.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Thank you, Doctor. I'll make sure to remember about the penicillin allergy.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I'll send the Cefdinir to your pharmacy now. Feel better, Olivia.
